title: Is it racist to like 'The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down'? - Quora

response.answer_text: The song has nothing to do with race. There's not a single word mentioning blacks or whites in the whole song. The song is about the burning of Richmond on April 2 and 3, 1865, according to the book "Southern Lady, Yankee Spy," which I happen to be reading just now. Contrary to popular knowledge, it was the Confederates themselves who set the city on fire in order to deprive the Union Army of any food, ammunition, or liquor. Their foolishness in dumping several hundred barrels of hard liquor into the streets caused the fire to spread throughout the city as burning whiskey ran through the gutters. (pp. 190-191.) The reason for the conflagration is that Gen. Sherman had completed his March from Atlanta to Savannah Georgia, then north through both Carolinas to meet up with Gen. Grant outside of Petersburg Virginia. Their combined forces, along with the cavalry of Philip Sheridan, defeated Gen. Robert E Lee, causing the fall of Richmond, the Confederate capital. "The Night they Drove Old Dixie Down" refers to the night of April 2, when the Confederate militia set the city on fire and destroyed resources on its way out of town. By the time Gen. Grant arrived the next morning, his primary task was putting out the fires that the Confederacy had set, even as Federal soldiers were raising the flag of the United States over the Confederate capital. The song is much better than the story; but neither of them has anything to do with slavery, nor with Blacks.
